questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with gradually worsening shortness of breath and fatigue. He has a history of tuberculosis treated 10 years ago. Physical examination reveals elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP) that rises paradoxically with inspiration. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Constrictive pericarditis:

  • The key words in question are Kussmaul sign- a paradoxical rise in JVP during inspiration and history of tuberculosis treatment indicates diagnosis as constrictive pericarditis. TB pericardial effusion is seen in untreated extrapulmonary TB and will have low voltage ECG.
  • Kussmaul sign is also seen in pulmonary embolism, RV infarction, restrictive cardiomyopathy, and advanced systolic heart failure.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct about grades of murmurs?

choices.text: Grade 1 murmur is very loud and audible even without a stethoscope
Grade 2 murmur is faint but audible with a stethoscope
Grade 4 murmur has a loud intensity without thrill
Grade 6 murmur is very faint and heard with difficulty

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Grade 2 murmur is faint but audible with a stethoscope:

Grading of Heart Murmurs - Levine scale (commonly used scale):

Grade 1

Very faint, heard only with difficulty.

Grade 2

Faint but audible with a stethoscope.

Grade 3

Moderately loud, easily audible.

Grade 4

Loud, with a palpable thrill.

Grade 5

Very loud, with a palpable thrill, heard with the edge of the stethoscope.

Grade 6

Extremely loud, audible without a stethoscope, with a palpable thrill.

questions.text:
Match the Following Murmurs to their characteristics


	
		
			
			Murmurs
			
			
			Characteristics 
			
		
		
			
			1. Mitral Stenosis
			
			
			A. High-pitched, crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard at the right upper sternal border.
			
		
		
			
			2. Aortic Stenosis
			
			
			B. Holosystolic murmur radiating to the axilla, often with a displaced apical impulse.
			
		
		
			
			3. Patent Ductus Arteriosus
			
			
			C. Early diastolic decrescendo murmur best heard along the left sternal border.
			
		
		
			
			4. Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy
			
			
			D. "Machine-like" continuous murmur heard best at the left infraclavicular area.
			
		
		
			
			5. Mitral Regurgitation
			
			
			E. Loud S1, opening snap, and low-pitched diastolic murmur heard best at the apex.
			
		
		
			
			6. Aortic Regurgitation
			
			
			F. Systolic ejection murmur, often with a crescendo-decrescendo pattern, best heard at the right upper sternal border, radiating to the carotids.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 1 - E, 2 - F, 3 - D, 4 - A, 5 - B, 6 - C:

Mitral Stenosis

Low-pitched diastolic murmur with opening snap, best at the apex. Accentuated by exercise or Valsalva's maneuver. 

Aortic Stenosis

Systolic ejection murmur, crescendo-decrescendo pattern, radiating to carotids

Patent Ductus Arteriosus

A continuous, machine-like murmur, heard at the left infraclavicular area

Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy

Harsh systolic murmur, crescendo-decrescendo pattern

Mitral Regurgitation

Holosystolic murmur radiating to the axilla

Aortic Regurgitation

Early diastolic decrescendo murmur, best heard at the left sternal border

Graham Steell Murmur

Early diastolic decrescendo murmur due to pulmonary regurgitation, heard best at the left upper sternal border.

Austin Flint Murmur

Low-pitched, rumbling diastolic murmur due to severe aortic regurgitation causing turbulent flow in the left ventricle.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with exertional chest pain and dyspnea. On physical examination, you note a harsh mid systolic murmur that is loudest at the left sternal border and increases in intensity with the Valsalva maneuver. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy:

  • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy causes a harsh mid-systolic murmur at the left sternal border that increases with Valsalva due to dynamic left ventricular outflow tract obstruction becoming more pronounced as preload decreases. Option B and C have ejection systolic murmurs that will decrease with Valsalva. ASD does not have shunt murmur.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents shortness of breath on exertion. Examination reveals a pansystolic murmur heard best at the apex of the heart, radiating to the axilla. The intensity of the murmur does not change with inspiration. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Chronic Mitral Regurgitation:

  • Mitral Regurgitation (MR) is characterized by a high-pitched holosystolic murmur that is best heard at the apex of the heart and radiates to the axilla. It does not change with inspiration. Usual cause is Rheumatic fever
  • Chronic tricuspid regurgitation (Option B) becomes louder on inspiration. Best heard in the lower left sternal edge.
  • Aortic Stenosis(Option C) presents with ejection systolic murmur. Best heard in the right second intercostal space, may radiate to the carotid arteries.
  • Acute mitral Regurgitation (Option D) causes early murmur due to rapid rise in left atrial pressure. Best heard in the apex, may radiate to the axilla.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is brought to the clinic for evaluation of high blood pressure detected during a routine check-up. On physical examination, the blood pressure is higher in the arms compared to the legs. A continuous murmur is heard over the back, near the left scapula. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Coarctation of the Aorta:

  • Coarctation of the aorta is the narrowing of the aortic arch, typically distal to the left subclavian artery, leading to higher blood pressure in the arms than in the legs and a continuous murmur over the back.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Takayasu arteritis is a large-vessel vasculitis that can cause pulse discrepancies and limb claudication, and does not typically present with a continuous murmur or blood pressure gradient between limbs.

Option C: Atrial septal defect causes a fixed split of the second heart sound and a systolic murmur due to increased flow across the pulmonary valve, but it does not cause blood pressure differences between the arms and legs.

Option D: Aortic dissection presents with sudden, severe chest or back pain and may cause unequal blood pressures in the arms and not associated with a continuous murmur.

questions.text: In aortic regurgitation, capillary pulsations can be seen in the nail beds. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Quincke’s sign:

  • Capillary pulsations seen in nail beds are called Quincke’s sign

Signs of Aortic Regurgitation:

deMusset's sign (Option C ruled out)

A head bob occurring with each cardiac cycle

Duroziez's sign (Option B ruled out)

A systolic and diastolic bruit heard when the femoral artery is partially compressed.

Hill's sign ( option D)

Popliteal cuff systolic pressure exceeds brachial pressure by more than 20  mmHg. 

Rosenbach's sign

Systolic pulsations of the liver.

Gerhard's sign

Systolic pulsations of the spleen.

questions.text: From the list of ECG findings given below which will not be seen in mitral stenosis?
questions.solution:
Tall tented T waves are seen in Hyperkalemia and not in mitral stenosis.

 

Tall R waves in V1–V3 (Option A) can be seen in mitral stenosis due to right ventricular hypertrophy secondary to pulmonary hypertension.
 

Bifid P wave (Option B) (also called P mitrale) is a classic sign of left atrial enlargement, commonly seen in mitral stenosis.
 

Atrial fibrillation (Option C) frequently occurs in mitral stenosis due to left atrial dilation and increased pressure.

questions.text: Which of the following schematic represents murmur of mitral stenosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A

Explanation:

Mitral stenosis presents with a mid-diastolic murmur with presystolic accentuation.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with presents with shortness of breath and pedal edema. Auscultation reveals a loud diastolic sound. Chest X-ray is given below. What is the treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Diuretics

Explanation:

The X-ray shows diffuse pericardial calcification along the left lateral and inferior wall of the heart. Loud pericardial sound indicates pericardial shudder. Diagnosis is constrictive pericarditis, and loop diuretics and aldosterone antagonists are used for treatment.

Pericardiocentesis (Option B) is indicated for pericardial effusion or cardiac tamponade, not for constrictive pericarditis where the pericardium is thickened and fibrotic rather than fluid-filled.


Beta-blockers (Option C) are generally not helpful in constrictive pericarditis and may worsen symptoms by reducing heart rate and cardiac output.


Glyceryl trinitrate (Option D) (nitroglycerin) is a vasodilator used in angina and heart failure but can worsen hypotension in constrictive pericarditis without improving the mechanical constraint.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman recently diagnosed with adenocarcinoma lung presents with sudden dyspnoea, tachycardia, and hypotension. Examination reveals elevated JVP and an abnormal drop of 15mm Hg in systolic blood pressure during inspiration. An ECG was performed and is given below. What is the most appropriate next step in management?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Pericardiocentesis

Explanation:

Patient shows signs of cardiac tamponade, including hypotension, elevated JVP and pulsus paradoxus (drop in systolic BP >10–15 mmHg on inspiration).

ECG shows electrical alternans. Urgent drainage of the pericardial fluid is required to relieve pressure on the cardiac chambers and restore cardiac output.


 

Intravenous diuretics (Option A) are not helpful in tamponade, as reducing preload can worsen hypotension and cardiac output.


Start vasopressors (Option C) may temporarily support blood pressure, but do not address the underlying mechanical compression, and delaying definitive treatment can be fatal.


Schedule elective cardiac surgery (Option D) is inappropriate for an emergency like tamponade; pericardiocentesis is the immediate life-saving measure.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of heart failure presents with worsening edema and jugular venous distention. You observe a steep x and steep y descent in the jugular venous waveform. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Constrictive pericarditis

Explanation:

Constrictive pericarditis typically causes a steep y descent to maximise ventricular filling before the calcified pericardial sac limits the diastole. Steep x is explained by atrial dilatation because of having to work against the resistance of stiff ventricles.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with palpitations and lightheadedness. His ECG shows an unequal number of P waves and R waves and his jugular venous pressure tracing is shown below. Which of the following conditions is responsible for this finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Complete heart block

Explanation:

Unequal R waves and P waves indicate AV dissociation. Cannon "a" waves occur when the atria contract against a closed tricuspid valve. Diagnosis is complete heart block.

Option A will have absent waves. Option D occurs after transmural MI causes the ventricular chamber to rupture. Tricuspid stenosis will cause large ‘a’ waves in JVP.

questions.text: Loud first heart sound (S1) in mitral stenosis indicates?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Increased left atrial pressure

Explanation:

Loud S1 is indicative of increased left atrial pressure, causing faster, abrupt closure of AV valves and, hence, a loud first heart sound.

Severe calcified mitral stenosis (Option C) leads to immobile, stiff valve leaflets, which reduce the intensity of S1, making it soft or absent, not loud.

  • The intensity of S1 is determined by the distance over which the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve must travel to return to its annular plane, leaflet mobility, LV contractility, and PR interval.
  • S1 is loud in rheumatic MS, hyperkinetic circulatory states and short PR interval.

 

Reduced LV compliance (Option A) typically affects diastolic filling but does not directly cause a loud S1; it may even reduce it in some conditions.

Hypertrophy of the right ventricle (Option D) may be a consequence of pulmonary hypertension due to mitral stenosis, but it does not directly affect the loudness of S1.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman with a history of ischemic cardiomyopathy, hypertension, and diabetes presents with worsening shortness of breath and fatigue. On physical examination, you hear both an S3 and an S4 heart sound. Which of the following best explains the presence of both heart sounds in this patient?

choices.text: Combined systolic and diastolic heart failure

questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Combined systolic and diastolic heart failure

Explanation:

 

The presence of both S3 and S4 is highly suggestive of combined systolic and diastolic heart failure. An S3 is due to increased ventricular filling pressure and occurs in systolic heart failure, while an S4 arises from atrial contraction against a stiff ventricle, commonly seen in diastolic dysfunction. The patient's history of ischemic cardiomyopathy and multiple comorbidities (hypertension, diabetes) further supports this diagnosis. S3 and S4 heard together is also called summation gallop.

 

Atrial fibrillation with mitral stenosis (Option A): An S4 is absent in atrial fibrillation because atrial contraction is ineffective. Mitral stenosis typically causes a loud S1 and an opening snap, not an S3 or S4.

 

Acute mitral regurgitation (Option B): Acute mitral regurgitation can cause an S3 due to rapid ventricular filling, but an S4 would be uncommon unless there is concurrent diastolic dysfunction, which is less likely in an acute setting.

 

Severe aortic stenosis (Option D): Aortic stenosis can cause an S4 due to the stiff left ventricle. However, an S3 is less likely unless there is concurrent left ventricular failure. Isolated aortic stenosis would not explain both sounds.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with palpitations. On examination, hyperdynamic precordium is noted with soft S1 and pansystolic murmur. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Mitral regurgitation

Explanation:

A soft S1 is heard in severe mitral regurgitation due to incomplete closure of the mitral valve, as blood flows back into the left atrium during systole. The murmur heard is a pansystolic murmur. The closest option of Hyperthyroidism is ruled out as it has a loud S1 with ejection systolic murmur with hyperdynamic precordium.

 

Mitral stenosis (Option B): Mitral stenosis typically causes a loud S1 due to the forceful closure of a stiffened mitral valve.

 

Tachycardia (Option D): Rapid heart rate can cause a louder S1, as the mitral valve closes more forcefully during fast cardiac cycles.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the ER with recurrent episodes of palpitations, dizziness, and occasional chest discomfort. Auscultation shows loud S1 and normal split S2. An ECG of the condition is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) Syndrome

Explanation:

ECG shows short PR interval, delta wave ( red marking) , and wide QRS complex, diagnostic of Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) Syndrome. Loud S1 is explained by tachycardia due to fast conduction via the bundle of kent.

Atrial Fibrillation (Option A): ruled out as P waves are visible.

Myocardial Infarction (Option C): ruled out as it causes ST elevation or depression with T wave changes

Brugada syndrome (option D) has coved or saddleback ST segment elevation.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought my mother as he gets very breathless during physical activities and had hospitalization for recurrent pneumonia episodes. Inspection shows a right parasternal heave, no cyanosis and auscultation reveals a systolic ejection murmur. Which is correct auscultatory finding seen in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Wide split fixed S2

Explanation:

The given clinical features of recurrent pneumonia episodes, right parasternal heave indicate shunting from L to R. Ejection systolic murmur is flow murmur of Atrial Septal Defect . It causes a wide split fixed S2 because of increased right heart blood flow, leading to delayed pulmonic valve closure. VSD presents at younger age with CHF and pansystolic murmur. PDA presents in neonatal period with continous murmur and narrow split S2.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl presents to the clinic with a history of recurrent respiratory infections and exercise intolerance. On physical examination, a holosystolic murmur is noted at the left lower sternal border. Which of the following is correct about heart sound finding in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Wide split variable S2

Explanation:

 

The given clinical features are of Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) which presents with a wide split variable S2.

 

Wide Fixed split S2 (Option A) occurs in conditions like atrial septal defect (ASD), where the split remains constant during respiration due to continuous right heart volume overload, which is not seen in VSD.

 

Paradoxical split S2 (Option B) happens when A2 occurs after P2, often due to conditions like HOCM with severe LV obstruction or severe aortic stenosis. It is not typical for VSD.

 

Narrow split S2 (Option C) indicates a delayed closure of the aortic valve but is not characteristic of VSD, where increased right-sided volume typically causes a wider split.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with progressive dyspnea and occasional dizziness. On auscultation, a harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur is noted at the left sternal border, which increases with the Valsalva maneuver. There is also evidence of a jerky carotid pulse. Which of the following will be heard on auscultation in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Paradoxical split S2

Explanation:

The clinical features suggest Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy (HOCM) with severe left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. It can delay the closure of the aortic valve (A2). This leads to the paradoxical splitting of S2, where A2 occurs after P2, causing the split to be heard during expiration.

 

Wide split S2 (Option A): This occurs when there is a delayed closure of the pulmonic valve (P2), causing an exaggerated split that increases during inspiration. Common in conditions like right bundle branch block (RBBB) or pulmonic stenosis.

 

Fixed split S2 (Option B): The split remains constant throughout the respiratory cycle, typically seen in atrial septal defect (ASD), due to continuous right heart volume overload.

 

Physiological split S2 (Option D): A normal finding where the split between A2 and P2 increases during inspiration and disappears during expiration due to increased venous return delaying P2.

questions.text: Narrow split S2 heart sound is heard in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Aortic stenosis

Explanation:

Narrow split S2 occurs in aortic stenosis because delayed closure of the aortic valve brings the A2 (aortic component) closer to P2 (pulmonic component).

  

Mitral regurgitation (Option A): In mitral regurgitation, the S2 sound is typically unaffected. However, an S3 sound (due to volume overload) may be heard.

 

Atrial septal defect (ASD) (Option C): In ASD, a wide and fixed split S2 is heard due to increased right-sided volume, which delays the closure of the pulmonic valve (P2).

 

Pulmonary hypertension (Option D): This can lead to a delayed P2, causing a wide split S2, not a narrow split.

questions.text:
Match the following

 


	
		
			
			Heart sound 
			
			
			Condition seen 
			
		
		
			
			1) Wide Split S2
			
			
			a) RBBB
			
		
		
			
			2) Paradoxical Splitting S2
			
			
			b) Mitral regurgitation
			
		
		
			
			3) Fixed Splitting S2
			
			
			c) LBBB
			
		
		
			
			4) Narrow Split S2
			
			
			d) Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy 
			
		
		
			
			 
			
			
			e) ASD
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-e, 4-d

 

Correct match:

Condition

Type of Split

1)Wide split

Mitral regurgitation due to early A2

2)Paradoxical split

LBBB due to delayed closure of A2

3)Fixed Splitting

ASD

4)Narrow splitting

Dynamic out flow tract obstruction will cause more time for blood to exit from left side. This causes delayed closure of A2 causing narrow split S2

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes with a history of fever, chest pain, weight loss, and night sweats. During cardiac auscultation, the physician notes a characteristic sound that persists on breath holding. ECG shows global ST segment elevation with concavity upwards. What is this finding called on auscultation known as?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Pericardial friction rub

Explanation:

Auscultatory finding is pericardial friction rub as it persists on breath holding that differentiates it from pleural rub. ECG finding of global ST segment elevation  indicates acute pericarditis. Possible etiology is Tuberculosis that will require more workup.

Opening snap (Option A) is a high pitch sound heard in cases of mitral stenosis, follows S2, occurring in early diastole.

 

Pericardial knock (Option C) also known as pericardial shudder is seen in cases of calcification around the heart in patients after treatment with ATT.

 

Pleural rub(Option D) is best heard in the phase of deep inspiration and disappears on breath holding.

questions.text: Which of the following features would raise suspicion for a diagnosis of Carney complex?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Presence of skin pigmentation abnormalities

Explanation:

The Carney complex is familial cause of Atrial myxomas + skin lesions (pigmentation) + Endocrine abnormalities like Cushing syndrome, acromegaly, multinodular goiter and precocious puberty. 

 

Atrial Myxomas:

 

Introduction

Most common primary cardiac tumors in adults.

Location

Often found in the left atrium.

Types

-Sporadic.

-Familial: Carney Complex (Myxomas + skin lesions + Endocrinopathies).

questions.text: During the cardiac cycle, the closing of the aortic valve takes place at ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Start of isovolumetric relaxation

Explanation:

Isovolumetric relaxation occurs immediately after the aortic and pulmonary valves close, which corresponds to the second heart sound. It has passive filling of atria.

Option A Isovolumetric contraction ending will still be having semilunar valves in open state .

Option B will have opening of mitral and tricuspid valves

Option D will cause the opening of A2 and P2. Option
